topic.title: HP Helion 1.2 Development Platform: Installing the Horizon UI for ALS, DBaaS, and Marketplace

body.p: This document shows how to install the Horizon UI for the Application Lifetime Service (ALS), Database as a Service (DBaaS), and Marketplace Services.

p.note: You will need to download and install the Horizon UI separately for each service you wish to upgrade.

section.title: Step 1: Retrieve the ALS, DBaaS, and Marketplace Service Updates from CODN
section.p: Use the Helion Development Platform UI to check CODN for a new Service Update for ALS, DBaaS, or Marketplace.

If there are new Service Updates for ALS, DBaaS, or Marketplace, retrieve them from CODN. This will retrieve the installation packages from CODN and push them into a container in Swift within your local cloud.

section.title: Step 2: Install the ALS, DBaaS, and Marketplace Service Updates
Preparation
section.p: You will need the following pieces of information in order to run the service updates.

row.entry: The IP address of the base node for your Helion installation.
The IP address of the seed node for your Helion installation.
The username of a cloud admin that has rights to perform a service update for the selected service (ALS, DBaaS, or Marketplace).
The password of a cloud admin that has rights to perform a service update for the selected service (ALS, DBaaS, or Marketplace).
The private key file for the heat-admin user. Usually available within the root user account on the seed node here: ~/.ssh/id_rsa
The Swift container that contains the service update. Defaults to als-horizon-ui for ALS. Defaults to dbaas-horizon-ui for DBaaS. Defaults to murano-dashboard-horizon-ui for Marketplace.
The filename of the ALS, DBaaS, or Marketplace service update. This can typically can be found inside the above container in Swift.

section.title: Let's get to it!
section.p: a) SSH to the seed node of your cloud:
section.codeblock:
# SSH to the base node ssh USERNAME@BASE_NODE_IP
# Become root sudo su (will prompt for password)
# SSH to the seed node ssh SEED_NODE_IP
section.p: b) Ensure your environment has the proper credentials to perform the download from Swift:
section.codeblock: # For ALS: Source the overcloud credentials to reach Swift export TE_DATAFILE="/root/tripleo/ce_env.json" source /root/tripleo/tripleo-incubator/overcloudrc # For DBaaS and Marketplace: overcloud credentials needed here source admin_over_creds
section.p: c) Use the Swift client to download the Service Update:
section.codeblock:
# List the contents of the Swift container for the desired service update # ALS swift list als-horizon-ui
# DBaaS swift list dbaas-horizon-ui
# Marketplace swift list murano-dashboard-horizon-ui
# Take note of the name of the file within each container # ex: SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME.tar.gz
# Download the installation file swift download CONTAINER_NAME SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME
section.p: d) Once the file is downloaded, unzip/tar the file:
e) Go to the newly created folder and execute the install script, passing in the location of the private key of the heat-admin account:
section.codeblock:
# For ALS: Source undercloud creds from the same location as the overcloudrc source /root/tripleo/tripleo-incubator/undercloudrc
# For DBaaS and Marketplace: Source undercloud creds source admin_under_creds
# Fire up the install! cd SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME ./install.sh HEAT_ADMIN_KEY

section.title: Step 3: Configure each service
section.p: Return to the Helion Development Platform UI and click on "Configure" to configure each service.
